verses.text: But you, O LORD, be not far off; O my Strength, come quickly to help me.
Deliver my life from the sword, my precious life from the power of the dogs.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 22 This psalm is well known for its many citations and allusions in the New Testament (Matt. 27:35, 39, 43, 46; John 19:23, 24, 28; Heb. 2:12). The psalm, like Ps. 69, expresses the suffering of Christ, the Son of David, dying at the hands of wicked men.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:19–21
rsbNotes.text: 22:19–21 After the laments and confessions of trust comes the climax, an appeal to the Lord. Notice that the enemies are named in reverse: humans, dogs, lions, and oxen.

verses.text: Rescue me from the mouth of the lions; save me from the horns of the wild oxen.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:21
rsbNotes.text: 22:21 You have rescued. The assurance of being heard is also present in other psalms of lament (3:4; 28:6; cf. 27:13; 34:4, 6; 38:15; 118:5, 21).

verses.text: I will declare your name to my brothers; in the congregation I will praise you.
You who fear the LORD, praise him! All you descendants of Jacob, honor him! Revere him, all you descendants of Israel!

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:22
rsbNotes.text: 22:22 I will tell. The thankful praise of the psalmist will be offered as the payment of his vows (v. 25). In Heb. 2:12 this verse is applied to Christ, who leads the praise of the great congregation.

verses.text: For he has not despised or disdained the suffering of the afflicted one; he has not hidden his face from him but has listened to his cry for help.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:24
rsbNotes.text: 22:24 he has not hidden his face. Christ’s enemies despised Him, but God did not.

verses.text: From you comes the theme of my praise in the great assembly; before those who fear you will I fulfill my vows.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:25
rsbNotes.text: 22:25 my vows I will perform. Mention of vows is common in psalms of lament (13:6; 27:6; 35:18; 54:6; 69:30, 31; cf. 51:16; 116:13, 14). The sufferer promises to bring a thanksgiving when his prayer is answered (Lev. 7:16; 22:23; Deut. 12:6, 7).

verses.text: The poor will eat and be satisfied; they who seek the LORD will praise him- may your hearts live forever!

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:26
rsbNotes.text: 22:26 shall eat and be satisfied. Perhaps a reference to the sacrificial meal of the Old Testament peace offering, when the vow is paid and the worshipers are included.

verses.text: All the ends of the earth will remember and turn to the LORD, and all the families of the nations will bow down before him,
for dominion belongs to the LORD and he rules over the nations.
All the rich of the earth will feast and worship; all who go down to the dust will kneel before him- those who cannot keep themselves alive.
Posterity will serve him; future generations will be told about the Lord.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:27
rsbNotes.text: 22:27 All the ends of the earth. The scope of praise expands, showing the prophetic reference to Christ and the New Testament church.

verses.text: They will proclaim his righteousness to a people yet unborn- for he has done it.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 22:31
rsbNotes.text: 22:31 that he has done it. The final victory of salvation is accomplished by Christ (John 19:30).
